I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed investment program is a multitranche financing facility which aims to 
improve basic urban services and promote the local economy in priority aimag (province) capitals 
and soum (subunit of an aimag) centers of Mongolia.1 The geographically targeted and integrated 
approach of the program will focus on priority regional urban clusters (RUCs) that have the 
potential to promote a more resilient and diversified economy to deliver inclusive and sustainable 
growth.2 The program will be aligned with the following impact: more sustainable development in 
Mongolia driven by multisector economy and ecological balance achieved. The outcome is 
population and private sector in targeted RUCs benefitted from improved urban and economic 
facilities and services. The outputs of the program are (i) municipal infrastructure and urban 
services in targeted areas improved, (ii) economic infrastructure and facilities in targeted areas 
improved, (iii) road linkages within targeted urban regions increased, and (iv) capacity in program 
and institutional management strengthened. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The transaction technical assistance (TA) will help the Government of Mongolia to prepare 
the investment program, which is a complex and multisector undertaking that requires full scale 
due  diligence  in  technical,  economic,  financial,  social,  resettlement,  environmental,  and 
institutional aspects, including in-depth local urban and socioeconomic assessments.3 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
 
3.  The preparatory work for the investment program and feasibility study are summarized 
below. 
 
4.  Output  1:  Economic  and  urban  development  strategy  formulated  and  project 
components identified. 
(i)   Urban  development  law.  This  suboutput  will  (a)  review  the  current  urban 
development law and other relevant laws together with the urban development 
secondary regulations, norms, and codes; (b) provide technical and urban inputs 
on the current draft law, urban development secondary regulations, and the city 
                                                
1  The proposed TA and program with original title of “Mongolia Secondary Cities and Soum Centers Development 
Investment Program,” is included in Asian Development Bank (ADB). Country Operations Business Plan: Mongolia, 
2017–2019. Manila. The title was revised to better reflect the objectives and content of the program. The tentative 
total cost of the program is estimated at $700 million. The maximum financing amount available under the 
multitranche financing facility is expected to be $600 million. The ADB financing from ordinary capital resources and 
concessional ordinary capital resources is expected to reach $360 million (51.4%). ADB-administered cofinancing 
from ADB trust funds and development partners is expected to reach $240 million (34.3%). Cofinancing may be 
provided as loans or grants, and may be parallel or joint. The government will finance $100 million (14.3%) of the 
total cost. The total cost of Tranche 1 is estimated at $200 million. 
2 As discussed in the approved concept paper, the National Urban Assessment for Mongolia has identified priority RUC 
systems as key assets to catalyze local urban economic growth. Upgrading infrastructure and creating synergies 
between economic and urban development in the RUCs will increase economies of agglomeration and critical mass, 
making RUCs a powerful engine of socioeconomic improvement. Tranche 1 will target RUCs with high potential for 
growth and high concentration of manufacturing enterprises while still lagging in terms of investment: (i) west RUC, 
consisting of Olgii, Hovd, and Ulanngom aimag capitals and surrounding soums; and (ii)  east RUC consisting of 
Choibalsan and surrounding soums. Also, investing in these two RUCs that are located beside the western and 
eastern country borders will promote regional integration and improve connectivity and access to external markets. 
3 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 20 November 2017.

2 
and town planning and development norm BNBD 30-01-01; (c) provide relevant 
inputs  on  the  2030  Ulaanbaatar  master  plan  that  is  related  to  the  law; 
(d) recommend ease of doing business and other governance-related indicators to 
promote  local  employment  and  entrepreneurships;  and  (e)  support  the 
development of final legal document and relevant norms, codes, and regulations.  
 
(ii)   Regional urban development plan. In the selected RUCs, the following will be 
undertaken: (a) assess human settlement development and migratory dynamics; 
(b) analyze the urban and rural linkage and integration challenges; (c) assess the 
current  urban  infrastructure  shortages  (including  operation  and  maintenance 
challenges) and their impact on the environment and urban growth; (d) develop 
urban development scenarios, trends, and service demands; (e) study local natural 
resources available to sustain urban growth for each key human settlements; 
(f) formulate an urban cluster and corridor development strategy; and (g) agree on 
the urban development scenario and develop an urban development plan including 
vision, strategic objectives, and targets and indicators in accordance with the 
economic development plan. 
  
(iii)   Regional economic and business development plan. Specific activities in the 
selected RUCs include: (a) undertake a sound analysis of the economic and 
industrial situation; (b) review the local situation in national and international 
contexts;  (c) identify  the  main  economic  actors  and  assess  the  business 
development trends and potential; (d) assess the environmental impacts of existing 
industries and enterprises; (e) formulate a regional business development plan and 
a  job  creation  plan  using  clear  vision,  strategic  objectives,  and  targets  and 
indicators; (f) identify current physical bottlenecks and policy issues to develop 
strategic objectives, identify physical (urban and economic infrastructure, services, 
facilities) and non-physical actions (policies, regulation, capacity, institutional) 
necessary to achieve the plan (especially identified main rules and regulations that 
support or impede business creation and small- and medium-sized enterprise 
development); and (g) synchronize and synergize the economic and business plan 
with the urban development plan.  
 
(iv)   Local development plan and priority components. Combining both urban and 
economic development plans, this suboutput will (a) produce a local development 
plan with specific focus on green development and poverty reduction and social 
development, (b) select priority aimag capitals and soum centers for investment, 
(c) formulate a model for comprehensive and integrated development for aimag 
capitals and soum centers, (d) develop a regional and cluster approach to share 
and optimize both urban and economic infrastructure, (e) identify local urban-rural 
economic potential synergies and linkages, and (f) identify priority components to 
be financed to meet the economic and urban development strategic objectives and 
vision. Local development plans (a) will also assess the risks associated with 
extreme weather events (especially dzuds)4 and consequences for rural-urban 
migration, and find ways to mitigate them, and (b) should be in line with the 
National Program on Reduction of Air and Environment Pollution, 2017–2025 and 
                                                
4 Dzud is a Mongolian term for a severe winter in which large number of livestock die, primarily due to starvation caused 
by lack of grass pasture, and in other cases, directly from the cold.

3 
the  proposed  policy-based  loan  on  Ulaanbaatar  Air  Quality  Improvement 
Program.5 
 
5.  Output 2: Investment program prepared and feasibility study completed.  
(i)   Component design. This suboutput will review the technical design of all program 
components to make sure they are (a) technically sound and socially inclusive; (b) 
environmentally  sustainable,  compatible  with  local  conditions,  and  meet  all 
relevant technical standards and safeguard requirements; and (c) suitable for 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) financing support. Based on the analyses and 
best national and international practices, the scope and the technical design of 
each program component will be refined and finalized. 
 
(ii)   Economic analysis. Full economic analyses of the program will be conducted, 
including  contingent  valuation  survey  and  analysis,  least-cost  analyses,  cost 
effectiveness analyses, and affordability analyses, where applicable, to ensure 
that economic analyses are carried out in accordance with the revised Guidelines 
for the Economic Analysis of Projects and the 10 key areas of economic analysis.6 
Economic rationale will be developed and economic justification will be evaluated 
for each program component and the program as a whole. The required appendix 
for the report and recommendation of the President (RRP) will be prepared.  
 
(iii)   Financial analysis. Financial review and analysis of each program component will 
be undertaken as well as detailed assessment of financial performance of the 
executing and implementing agencies in accordance with ADB guidelines.7 The 
required appendix for the RRP will be prepared, fund flow and disbursement 
mechanisms  of  the  ensuing  project  based  on  the  results  of  the  financial 
management assessment will be designed, and the need for use of advance fund 
and statement of expenditure (SOE) procedures will be identified. In case the 
advance fund and SOE procedure are proposed, assessment on the relevant 
entity’s capacity to manage the advance fund and SOE procedure, particularly 
without specific ceilings, will be conducted. 
 
(iv)   Institutional  and  financial  arrangements.  The  program  will  strengthen 
regulatory,  financial,  and  institutional  framework  and  establish  sustainable 
solutions  for  service  delivery.  The  following  activities  will  be  undertaken: 
(a) analyze all different options to leverage private sector support and identify the 
best combination of investment instruments available, (b) analyze advantages and 
challenges of having private sector participation and inform on the possibility to 
structure  public–private  partnership,  (c)  analyze  suitable  public–private 
partnership transactions, and (d) develop mechanisms to ensure the sustainability 
of the implementation arrangements.

(v)   Poverty and social assessment. A qualified survey institute will be engaged to 
conduct a household survey and community consultations for poverty and social 
analysis in accordance with ADB requirements.8 A consultation and participation 
plan will be prepared, key informant and focus group discussions will be conducted, 
survey data will be analyzed, and a poverty and social analysis will be prepared, 
which will provide the basis for recommendations for design, implementation, and 
monitoring  to  strengthen  the  program's  development  impacts.  Based  on  this 
analysis, a social action plan and a summary poverty reduction and social strategy, 
in accordance with ADB guidelines and templates will be prepared.  
 
(vi)   Gender action plan. In accordance with ADB guidelines,9 a gender action plan 
will be prepared with the objective of ensuring that the program design includes 
and maximizes benefits for women and meets effective gender mainstreaming 
categorization requirements. Sex-disaggregated baseline/proxy data for targets to 
be set in the investment program will be prepared and gender analysis will be 
conducted to identify gender needs and constraints of project beneficiaries.  
 
(vii)   Community participation plan and public awareness campaign program. 
Through participatory approach, a comprehensive communications strategy and 
detailed  development  plan for  community  involvement  and  public  awareness 
based on the 2012 Guidelines on Participation will be prepared.10 
 
(viii)   Environmental assessment. This will support the Ministry of Construction and 
Urban Development (MCUD) to prepare and submit an official request to the 
Ministry of Environment and Tourism to conduct a general environmental impact 
assessment (EIA). Should the Ministry of Environment and Tourism conclude that 
a detailed EIA is needed for the program, support to MCUD in contracting a 
licensed EIA institute, and supervising the preparation of the detailed EIA report 
will be provided. The initial environmental examination and the environmental 
assessment and review framework will be prepared to meet the requirements 
specified in ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). The initial environmental 
examination, to be prepared in English and Mongolian, will include (a) public 
consultation,  (b) assessment  of  impacts  and  risks,  and  (c) development  of 
environmental  management  plan.  Further,  a  climate  risk  and  vulnerability 
assessment considering risks associated with extreme weather events (especially 
dzuds) and consequences for rural-urban migration will be prepared. 
 
(ix)   Climate  change  resiliency.  This  suboutput  will  assess  how  the  investment 
program will (a) be a powerful driver to improve the regulatory and enforcement 
framework  for  a  climate  responsive  urban/regional  planning  and  local  green 
infrastructure and construction; and (b) lead transformational impacts on policies, 
institutions, and sector capacity for energy efficient construction material and

techniques, effective community participation, renewable energy systems, efficient 
supply chains for renewable energy systems, and comprehensive urban planning 
that will combine climate resilience, social cohesion, and economic opportunities. 
Thus, the project will serve as an important demonstration initiative that can be 
replicated within the priority aimags and soums and in other Mongolian cities and 
administrative divisions.  
 
(x)   Assessment of social impacts for involuntary resettlement. Social impact 
assessment  for  involuntary  resettlement  will  be  conducted  to  cover  the 
identification of past, present, and future potential impacts based on (a) meaningful 
consultations, (b) baseline data analysis including census and asset inventory, 
(c) gender-disaggregated  information  pertaining  to  the  economic  and  socio-
cultural conditions of the affected persons, (d) analysis of potential impacts on 
vulnerable individuals and groups, and (e) replacement cost survey. The social 
impact assessment for involuntary resettlement, including measures to enhance 
or at least restore the livelihoods of the affected persons, potential benefit-sharing, 
and opportunities resulting from socioeconomic development, establishment of 
grievance redress mechanism, institutional arrangements, budget, schedule, and 
monitoring, will become the basis for the consultant to prepare the resettlement 
plans. Assistance to the government in the disclosure of the resettlement plans 
and in preparation of a resettlement framework for the investment program and 
subsequent tranches will be provided.  
 
(xi)   Ethnic  minority  (indigenous  peoples)  assessment  and  plan.  A  thorough 
scoping of ethnic minority issues will be conducted in the program area and, if 
deemed necessary, an ethnic minority development plan (with summary) and 
ethnic minority development framework for subsequent tranches, in accordance 
with ADB requirements will be prepared.11  
 
(xii)   Procurement  plan  and  procurement  documents.  A  comprehensive project 
procurement risk assessment of the implementing agency in accordance with ADB 
guidelines and template will be undertaken.12 Based on this assessment and 
technical  requirements  of  each  program  component,  a  procurement  plan  for 
Tranche 1 will be prepared. Support to the preparation of detailed terms of 
reference for consulting services packages and bidding documents for works and 
goods packages under Tranche 1 will be provided, including necessary guidance 
and technical support during consulting services selection. 
 
(xiii)   Institutional  strengthening  and  capacity  development  plan.  A  capacity 
development  plan  presenting  specific  actions  for  trainings  and  institutional 
strengthening  measures,  based  on  institutional  assessment,  financial 
management,  procurement,  planning,  technical  engineering,  operation  and 
maintenance,  and  program  management  capacities  of  MCUD  and  other 
concerned stakeholders will be prepared. 
 
(xiv)   Multitranche financing facility constituents. Relevant inputs to prepare the 
framework financing agreement constituents: sector road map, including specific

sector investment plans, strategic context, policy framework, investment program 
or investment plan, financing plan, undertakings, and periodic financing request 
for Tranche 1 will be provided. 
 
6.  Output 3: Aid effectiveness and project readiness enhanced. Technical inputs at the 
initial stage of program implementation will be provided to expedite the advance contracting and 
engagement of consulting firms for Tranche 1. Specific activities include (i) review of consulting 
services requirements and identification of appropriate selection methods; (ii) preparation of 
detailed terms of reference for consulting services contract packages, i.e., detailed design, 
construction supervision, and program management office support; (iii) support in the shortlisting 
of consulting firms, including preparation of requests for proposals and criteria for consultant 
recruitment, and in the evaluation of financial and technical proposals; (iv) guidance on program 
management  office  organization,  decision-making  structure,  and  institutional  setting  and 
operation; and (v) provide technical advice and training in the process of selection of consultants 
in accordance with ADB regulations.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
7.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,600,000, of which $1,500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
office  accommodation,  venues  for  workshops  and  training,  communication  facilities  for 
consultants, remuneration and per diem of counterpart staff, administrative support, and other in-
kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB 
to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  ADB will administer the TA, and engage a consulting firm and individual consultants in 
accordance with ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the 
associated project administration instructions and TA Staff Instructions.

9.  Consulting services. The TA will require 115 person-months of consulting inputs from 
14 international experts (40 person-months) and 16 national experts (75 person-months).13 ADB 
will select and engage a consulting firm using quality- and cost-based selection method, with 
90:10 quality–cost ratio and full technical proposal procedure.14 In addition, individual consultants 
will be engaged (i) to work on the urban development legal and regulatory framework; and (ii) after 
submission of the draft final report, to support start-up activities of the ensuing loan, on as need 
basis using the contingencies. Contingencies may be allocated to recruit additional experts based 
on needs that will emerge during TA implementation.  
 
10.  Additional support of approximately $300,000 will be sought from the Cities Development 
Initiative for Asia to include the west central Khangai RUC in the TA studies, strengthen the 
regional and local economic studies, update the National Urban Assessment for Mongolia, and 
upgrade the web-based mapping platform developed under the National Urban Assessment. The 
TA Supervision Unit officer will be responsible for preparing a TA completion report required by 
ADB, with copy to the Office of Cofinancing Operations. 
 
11.  Cofinancier requirements. A TA letter signing ceremony with press coverage will be 
organized. To enhance visibility, a representative from the Japanese Embassy in Mongolia will 
be invited. The TA will ensure clear references to the financial contribution of the Government of 
Japan during major project activities and for major outputs (i.e., workshops, publications, press 
releases, speeches); and use the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and Japan aid logos on 
correspondence,  workshop  material,  banners,  and  any  media  publication.  The  Japanese 
Embassy in Mongolia will be informed about the TA progress, milestones, and deliverable, 
especially when major changes in scope and objectives are required. Due to the proposed 
program’s interdependence with Japan International Cooperation Agency’s involvement in urban 
and regional development sector in Mongolia, close cooperation and coordination is expected in 
the future at the strategic and policy level, and at implementation and financing level. 
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
8.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 to the Government 
of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Preparing 
the Aimag and Soum Centers Regional Development Investment Program, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.
